title: F1 bosses delay decision on whether to CANCEL Japanese Grand Prix qualifying
text:
Formula One is the latest sport to be affected by Super Typhoon Hagibis after it was revealed bosses are considering cancelling qualifying at the Japanese Grand Prix.

Two Rugby World Cup matches have already been called off - with a third potentially to follow - and now F1 could also be forced to change its plans this weekend.

The tropical storm is classified as 'violent' by Japanese meteorologists, with wind speeds likely to exceed 160mph, and bosses are concerned for fans' safety.

Fans are enjoying the build-up to Japanese Grand Prix but qualifying could yet be cancelled

Typhoon Hagibis is being put on par with a category 5 hurricane with 160mph winds expected

In 2010 (pictured), the Japanese Grand Prix was severely affected by the adverse weather

F1's governing body say they are 'closely monitoring Typhoon Hagibis and its potential impact on the Japanese Grand Prix'.

A statement read: 'Every effort is being made to minimise disruption to the F1 timetable.

'However, the safety of fans, competitors and everyone at the Suzuka circuit remains the top priority.'

A decision on whether to cancel Saturday's qualifying is expected to come before the end of Friday, and will primarily be down to the local authorities, who will decide whether to close the track and advise people to stay indoors.

Max Verstappen and Charles Leclerc are among the drivers waiting to hear news on the race

The weather is okay in Suzuka at the moment but the typhoon is heading for land on Saturday

Lewis Hamilton waves to the fans back in 2010, where qualifying was postponed until Sunday

If the schedule is affected, it would not be the first time the Japanese Grand Prix has been changed due to the weather.

In both 2004 and 2010, qualifying had to be postponed and was then run on Sunday morning - before the race a few hours later in the afternoon.

If local authorities do not decide to close the track and force F1's hand, it is expected bosses will try desperately to stick to their planned schedule.
description: Formula One is the latest sport to be affected by Super Typhoon Hagibis after it was revealed bosses are considering cancelling qualifying at the Japanese Grand Prix.
